alternative_title: Limits on benefits for working-age people
body:
$!From April 2013 a limit will be put on the total amount of benefit that most people aged 16 to 64 can get. This is called a benefit cap.$!

If you’re affected, your Housing Benefit will go down to make sure that the total amount of benefit you get isn’t more than the cap level.

If you're already getting benefits and could be affected by the cap you’ll be contacted by the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP). They'll let you know what will happen to your benefits.

^Use the [benefit cap calculator](https://www.dwpe-services.direct.gov.uk/portal/page/portal/bcc/lp "benefit cap calculator"){:rel="external"} to find out if you’ll be affected, and how much your benefits could go down by.^

##What’s included

The cap will apply to the total amount that the people in your household get from the following benefits:

- [Bereavement Allowance](/bereavement-allowance "Bereavement Allowance")
- [Carer's Allowance](/carers-allowance "Carer's Allowance")
- [Child Benefit](/child-benefit "Child Benefit")
- [Child Tax Credit](/child-tax-credit "Child Tax Credit")
- [Employment and Support Allowance](/employment-support-allowance "Employment and Support Allowance") (unless you get the support component)
- [Guardian’s Allowance](/guardians-allowance "Guardian’s Allowance")
- [Housing Benefit](/housing-benefit "Housing Benefit")
- [Incapacity Benefit](/incapacity-benefit "Incapacity Benefit")
- [Income Support](/income-support "Income Support")
- [Jobseeker's Allowance](/jobseekers-allowance "Jobseeker’s Allowance")
- [Maternity Allowance](/maternity-allowance "Maternity Allowance")
- [Severe Disablement Allowance](/severe-disablement-allowance "Severe Disablement Allowance")
- [Widowed Parent's Allowance](/widowed-parents-allowance "Widowed Parent's Allowance") (or Widowed Mother’s Allowance or Widows Pension you started getting before 9 April 2001)

##How much is the benefit cap?

The level of the cap will be:

- £500 a week for couples
- £500 a week for single parents whose children live with them
- £350 a week for single adults who don't have children, or whose children don’t live with them

##Who won’t be affected?

You won’t be affected by the benefit cap if you qualify for [Working Tax Credit](/working-tax-credit "Working Tax Credit") (whether or not you claim it), or if you get any of the following benefits:

- [Disability Living Allowance](/dla-disability-living-allowance-benefit "Disability Living Allowance")
- Personal Independence Payment (from April 2013)
- [Attendance Allowance](/attendance-allowance "Attendance Allowance")
- [Industrial Injuries Disablement Benefit](/industrial-injuries-disablement-benefit "Industrial Injuries Disablement Benefit")
- [Employment and Support Allowance](/employment-support-allowance "Employment and Support Allowance"), if you get the support component
- [War Widow's or War Widower's Pension](/war-widow-pension "War Widow's or War Widower's Pension")

*[DWP]:Department for Work and Pensions
